sources.title: Articles on Smashing Magazine â€” For Web Designers And Developers

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Luis Ouriach)
articles.description: Part 2 concentrates on the key points from Luisâ€™ framework and practical tips about managing a design system that should be both robust and easy to adopt.
articles.title: Building Components For Consumption, Not Complexity (Part 2)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Brecht De Ruyte)
articles.description: Have you run into a situation where you need the padding of one element to align with the padding of another element? In this article, Brecht De Ruyte demonstrates the issue with a full-width slider component that breaks out of the main page container and shares a couple of techniques to keep it visually aligned with other elements on the page.
articles.title: CSS Scroll Snapping Aligned With Global Page Layout: A Full-Width Slider Case Study

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Luis Ouriach)
articles.description: Design systems can be of immense help, but failure to adopt them invalidates the hard work that goes into building the thing in the first place! In this two-part series of articles, Luis shares his experience with design systems and how you can overcome the potential pitfalls.
articles.title: Building Components For Consumption, Not Complexity (Part 1)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Geoff Graham)
articles.description: Starting in March 2024, Interaction to Next Paint will formally replace First Input Delay as a Core Web Vital metric. Learn how the two metrics differ, why we needed a new way to measure interaction responsiveness, and how you can start optimizing the performance of your site now for a seamless transition to the latest Core Web Vital metric.
articles.title: Preparing For Interaction To Next Paint, A New Web Core Vital

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Eduard Kuric)
articles.description: Five-second testing is a popular method of usability research used in the industry, yet in essence, its core belief boils down to virtually a superstition. Eduard Kuric looks under the hood at how first impressions are affected by various factors and how UX researchers and product owners can ensure that the userâ€™s first steps can get off on the right foot.
articles.title: Five-Second Testing: Taking A Closer Look At First Impressions (Case Study)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Juan Diego RodrÃ­guez)
articles.description: Discussing the decisions surrounding JavaScript prototypes, the article by Juan Diego Rodriguez scrutinizes their origin, examines missteps in the design, and explores how these factors have affected the way we write JavaScript today.
articles.title: How Marketing Changed OOP In JavaScript

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Oluwasanmi Akande)
articles.description: Git is designed to assure us that we can track a projectâ€™s files at different points in time. But it doesnâ€™t assure us that those files are always safe along the way. For those of you who have dealt with the sinking feeling that youâ€™ve irrevocably deleted and lost files, Sanmi has a couple of approaches that, in the right situations, may help bring them back.
articles.title: Recovering Deleted Files From Your Git Working Tree

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Cosima Mielke)
articles.description: Could there be a better way to welcome the new month than with a collection of desktop wallpapers? Weâ€™ve got some eye-catching designs to sweeten up the last few weeks of the year and, if youâ€™re celebrating, to get you in the holiday mood.
articles.title: Cold Days, Shining Lights (December 2023 Wallpapers Edition)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Sasha Denisova)
articles.description: In this article, Sasha guides you through crucial processes and factors to achieve a consistent brand presence across platforms. She offers an overview of the entire brand identity process, explores collaboration with UI teams, and provides essential details on the assets required for the successful implementation of a digital brand.
articles.title: Crafting A Killer Brand Identity For A Digital Product

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Geoff Graham)
articles.description: Weâ€™re living in somewhat of a CSS renaissance with new features, techniques, experiments, and ideas coming at us to an extent we havenâ€™t seen since â€œCSS3â€. Itâ€™s easy to feel overwhelmed when your profession seems to be advancing at breakneck speed, but Geoff Graham considers the ways â€œmodernâ€ CSS in 2023 has actually made CSS â€œeasierâ€ to write.
articles.title: A Few Ways CSS Is Easier To Write In 2023

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Facundo Giuliani)
articles.description: A well-designed composable system should not only consider the technical aspects but also take into account the nature of the content it handles. To help us with that, we can use a Headless Content Management system such as Storyblok.
articles.title: An Introduction To Full Stack Composability

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Temani Afif)
articles.description: In Part 1 of the series, Temani Afif demonstrated how creating ribbon patterns in CSS has evolved with the availability of new CSS features. In this second installment of this brief two-part series, we look at two additional ribbon variations that introduce techniques for masking a repeated background gradient in CSS.
articles.title: CSS Responsive Multi-Line Ribbon Shapes (Part 2)

articles.author: hello@smashingmagazine.com (Victor Yocco & Dana Daniels)
articles.description: Product teams benefit from knowing their usersâ€™ needs and how they respond to product updates as they build out the roadmap of a product. This article covers Voice of Customer programs and is aimed at those who work on a product team as well as executives who are looking for how to better inform your products using insight from users.
articles.title: Creating And Maintaining A Voice Of Customer Program

articles.author: Beau Carnes
articles.description: Remix and Strapi go together like git merges and zero conflicts - a rare yet delightful occurrence in the world of web development. We just published a full course on the freeCodeCamp.org YouTube channel that will teach you to create full stack apps with Remix and Strapi. Paul Bratslavsky created
articles.title: Use Remix and Strapi to Create Full Stack Apps

articles.author: Reed Barger
articles.description: Props are a common stumbling block when moving from JavaScript to React. In reality, using props in React components is almost identical to using arguments in plain JavaScript functions. Let's take a quick look at what props are in React through some helpful animations. These will help you visualize how
articles.title: Learn React Props â€“ The Animated Guide

articles.author: SUDHEER KUMAR REDDY GOWRIGARI
articles.description: In the dynamic world of web development, creating websites that are accessible to all users, including those with disabilities, is not just a best practice â€“ it's a necessity.  Web accessibility ensures that everyone, regardless of their abilities, can perceive, understand, navigate, and interact with the web. This inclusivity
articles.title: Web Accessibility Best Practices â€“ How to Ensure Everyone Can Use Your Website

articles.author: Ijelekhai Faith Olohijere
articles.description: At Figma Config 2023, the Figma team unveiled a lot of new features â€“ including variables. The launch of variables in Figma offers designers a new approach that helps them make their designs more flexible and adaptable.  In this tutorial, you'll learn what variables in Figma are, and how
articles.title: How to Use Variables in Figma â€“ A Handbook for Beginners

articles.author: Quincy Larson
articles.description: Today I'm joined by Kylie Ying. She's a software engineer and a teacher at freeCodeCamp. We talk about Kylie's 5 years at MIT, her time at CERN working on the Large Hadron Collider, competitive figure skating, and even poker-playing AIs. Tell your friends about the freeCodeCamp podcast. Let's inspire more
articles.title: Podcast: Kylie Ying on MIT, CERN, Figure Skating, and Poker AI

articles.author: Nathan Sebhastian
articles.description: Hello friends! In this article, I'm going to show you how to use the â€œasync/awaitâ€ special syntax when handling JavaScript Promises. If you don't know or need a refresher on JavaScript promises, you can read my previous article: How JavaScript Promises Work â€“ Tutorial for Beginners [/news/javascript-promise-object-explained/]. You'll need to
articles.title: How to Use Async/Await in JavaScript â€“ Explained with Code Examples

articles.author: Beau Carnes
articles.description: The Microsoft Azure Fundamentals Certification is for technology professionals who want to demonstrate foundational knowledge of cloud concepts in general and Microsoft Azure in particular. This exam is a common starting point in a journey towards a career in Azure. We just posted a full exam-prep course on the freeCodeCamp.org
articles.title: Azure Fundamentals Certification (AZ-900) â€“ Pass the Exam With This Free 8-Hour Course

articles.author: Beau Carnes
articles.description: Testing code is crucial because it ensures the reliability, security, and proper functioning of products or systems, identifying potential issues before they become significant problems. We just published a course on the freeCodeCamp.org YouTube channel that will teach you how to test JavaScirpt code with the Jest testing framework. Tomi
articles.title: How to Test JavaScript  Code with Jest

articles.author: Ijeoma Igboagu
articles.description: When developing applications, you often need to get data from an API. This lets you deliver dynamic and often-updated content within your application. You'll want to retrieve this data as you may need to interact with external services, communicate with a distant server, or access a database. In this article,
articles.title: How to Fetch API Data in React

articles.author: Okoye Victor Chukwuebuka
articles.description: When you're developing programs, certain services can block or slow down the speed of your application. For example, CPU-intensive tasks like audio transcribing or file processing. So you might wonder â€“ how do you make sure your application runs without breaking? To handle this, you can send tasks to a
articles.title: How to Set Up Message Queues for Async Tasks with RabbitMQ in Nest.js Apps
